H0.text: The molecules briefly forming chemical bonds with nearby objects cause a very small dust particle to jiggle slightly when observed under a microscope in a liquid, as the dust interacts with the liquid molecules.

H1.text: The molecules are always in random motion, causing a very small dust particle to jiggle slightly when observed under a microscope in liquid due to its interaction with the molecules.

H2.text: The molecules transfer an electric charge to the dust particles, causing the very small piece of dust in a liquid to jiggle slightly when observed under a microscope.

H3.text: The molecules frequently change shape, which causes a very small dust particle to jiggle slightly when observed under a microscope in a liquid due to the interaction between the dust and the liquid molecules.

A4.text: the direction of the force of atomic bombardment is constantly changing, and at different times the particle is hit more on one side than another, leading to the seemingly random nature of the motion

A5.text: Einstein published a paper in which he modelled the motion of the pollen particles as being moved by individual water molecules
